title: My lightbulb moment: Snack entrepreneur Ilana Taub
text:
Ilana Taub, 33, co-founded Snact, which makes sustainable snacks from waste fruit, with her husband, Michael, 33, in 2013. She is mother to ten-month-old Evie.

I remember becoming aware of climate change at school and thinking: ‘That’s not right.’ I also met my husband Michael there and we ended up doing the same Master’s course in environmental technology at Imperial College London, so we stayed friends.

It was here that we learned that 30 per cent to 40 per cent of food is wasted every year, globally.

Ilana Taub, 33, (pictured) co-founded sustainable snacks company Snact, after becoming driven to do something about food waste across the globe

The scale is shocking — you can’t really grasp what it looks like. At a time when we’re facing the challenge of feeding growing populations, it seems insane.

After graduating in 2011, we wondered what we could do about it. But the solution wasn’t clear. So I got a job in sustainability at The Institute of Chartered Accountants, and Michael moved to Denmark to work with wind turbines.

Yet he would often come back here for work. We would meet up to brainstorm business ideas and we visited wholesale markets to see how much produce was wasted.

Anything misshapen or ‘ugly’ didn’t make it to market. Then, huge amounts were thrown out once they passed their best-before dates — this included the 1.6 billion UK apples that are thrown out each year.

Then, in May 2013, a friend told us about an ancient Middle Eastern practice of preserving fruit, by blending and dehydrating it.

This was our lightbulb moment. I met Michael at the Southbank Centre and we said: ‘Let’s go for it!’ We quit our jobs and began to experiment with recipes for our own snacks, made with fruit that was ‘unsaleable’ but still usable.

Fruit jerky, £3.99, snact.co.uk

In autumn 2013, we launched Snact, with support from an online campaign with Crowdfunder. Each bag of fruit jerky is made using one apple plus other fruit, which would have been thrown away. It’s all produced in the UK and the packaging is compostable.

At first, we were selling only at London markets, but it was such a hit, we were soon stocked in small shops.

In 2016, Michael and I got married and today, we have a range of three flavours, which are sold in Planet Organic, Ocado and on Amazon.

I never thought I would end up working with my partner, but it’s been absolutely incredible. I think more people should do it!

You could get crowdfunding support and funding to start your own business at natwestbackherbusiness.co.uk
description: Ilana Taub, 33, is the co-founder of sustainable snacks company Snact. She revealed her inspiration came after learning about the Middle Eastern practice of preserving fruit.
authors: Florence Scordoulis For The Daily Mail
